awd_titl_txt: Sustainable Summer Bridges from Campus to Campus: Retention Models for Transitioning Underrepresented Engineering Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The impetus for the Sustainable Bridges from Campus to Campus study is to address the urgent need to expand the pool of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) graduates, especially African American and Hispanic students. Long-term improvements in the pipeline of a diverse STEM workforce start with sustaining effective bridge programs that can produce more engineering baccalaureates. To improve retention in engineering, this study will conduct academic enrichment programs for racially underrepresented engineering students at three points in their career at the Pennsylvania State University--entering freshmen, sophomores, and juniors. 

The goals of the study are to (a) increase retention in engineering among racially underrepresented students in the Penn State system, (b) develop long-term sustainability plans for these enrichment programs, and (c) compare retention rates in engineering depending on the campus location of the summer bridge and the student's transfer status within the University system. The conceptual model guiding this study is that retention in engineering is mediated by math performance in gateway courses and the strength of the cohort learning community (based on the Tinto model and theory). The bridges are designed to enhance both factors. Therefore to evaluate student learning and the efficaciousness of the math-intensive bridges, pre-calculus, calculus 1 and calculus 2 grades, and the size and quality of the academic social network in the semester following the bridges are examined. Matched groups is compared to evaluate the intervention. The primary outcome measure is retention in engineering in the junior year.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Disclaimer:

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

This report presents the final results for the “Sustainable Bridges from Campus to Campus” project (NSF IUSE # 1525367) funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) through the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) initiative (#1525367).  The project ran from 01/01/2016 to 12/31/2021. The purpose of the project was (1) to initiate three math-intensive summer bridge programs at three regional campuses of The Pennsylvania State University (i.e., Abington, Altoona, Berks) for incoming underserved Engineering majors, (2) support a math-intensive bridge program for incoming underrepresented Engineering students at the main University Park campus, and (3) support a math- and physics-intensive bridge program for rising second-year students in Engineering. The purpose of summer bridge programs is to support the transition to college and increase student success by focusing on math mastery, college-success skills, professional development, and relationship and community building. From 2016 to 2019, the bridge programs were residential or a day-program. In 2020, because of the COVID-19 pandemic, all bridge programs were virtual and synchronous. In 2021, there was a variety of bridge program administrations such as virtual, residential, and hybrid (virtual & residential).

The three goals of the “Sustainable Bridges” project were (1) to increase retention in Engineering among racially underrepresented Engineering students by extending a successful summer bridge model and transition program to regional campuses in the Pennsylvania State University system, (2) Develop long-term sustainability plans for these programs, and (3) Compare the efficacy of three different bridge models. The primary outcome measure was retention in baccalaureate Engineering majors following the entrance-to-major process at the beginning of the junior year (i.e., enrollment in a specific major). Secondary outcome measures were retention in STEM majors and the University.

We enrolled a total of 504 first-year engineering students across 6 cohorts enrolled in the summer bridge programs for freshmen Engineering students (called Engineering Ahead). Four cohorts were enrolled prior to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, and two cohort were enrolled during the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly a third of the participants were female (31%). Fifty-seven percent (57%) of the participants were underrepresented in Engineering (Native American, African American, Hispanic). Nearly a third of the Engineering Ahead participants were first-generation college students (31%).

 

To gauge the academic success of students who participated in the summer bridge programs, each participant was matched to a similar student who did not participate in our bridge programs. For four of the six cohorts, the bridge students earned higher grades in their first college math course. For two of the six cohorts, bridge participants also earned a higher grade point average after the first semester of college and after the first year of college compared to the comparison group. For students who completed the entrance-to-major process (typically at the end of the second year of college) in which they officially enter a specific engineering major, students who participated in our bridge programs were more likely to be retained as an engineering major and be retained as a major in a science, technology, engineering or math (STEM) major.

We enrolled a total of 180 rising-sophomore engineering students from throughout the Penn State system of regional campuses in the second-year summer bridge program (called Jump Start). We enrolled 5 cohorts of participants in Jump Start. Forty-four percent (44%) were female, 41 percent were racially underrepresented in Engineering, and 36 percent were first-generation college students. For participants who completed the entrance-to-major process (that is enrollment in a specific engineering major after the sophomore year), they were more likely to be retained in the engineering majors and STEM majors than similar students who did not participate in the Jump Start summer bridge program.

Because of their expense, summer bridge programs are difficult to sustain over time. Another positive result of the project is that three out of the four summer bridge programs for incoming first-year students have been partially sustained through local endowments, internal funds, and new external funding. Long-term improvements in the diversity of the engineering workforce will be enhanced by the long-term sustaining of summer bridge programs for underrepresented students in engineering.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/30/2022
Modified by: Peter J Butler
